thinkers.name: Bill Duane
thinkers.context: Engineer and innovator who worked at Google, Amazon, and other tech companies; co-creator of Search Inside Yourself program bridging ancient wisdom and AI ethics; now exploring Human-AI hybrid systems of care.

thinkers.name: Thomas Doctor
thinkers.context: Co-founder of Center For The Study Of Apparent Selves; developed the Stress-Care Loop framework connecting care to intelligence.

thinkers.name: Olaf Witkowski
thinkers.context: Co-founder of Center For The Study Of Apparent Selves; collaborating with Bill Duane on Human-AI hybrid systems research at Google X.

thinkers.name: Lisa Solomon
thinkers.context: Core founding member of Center For The Study Of Apparent Selves.

thinkers.name: Venerable Akira
thinkers.context: Buddhist teacher acknowledged for organizing the conference and supporting the work.

thinkers.name: Ajahn Chah
thinkers.context: Forest tradition Buddhist teacher whose lineage Bill Duane trained in for five years.

thinkers.name: Professor Ting
thinkers.context: Buddhist teacher who inspired Bill Duane through his relationship with his own teachers.

thinkers.name: U Kyar Kin
thinkers.context: Early figure in bringing mindfulness and Buddhist practices to broader audiences.

thinkers.name: Evans
thinkers.context: Author of 'The Blind Spot,' addressing limitations of reductionist science and hidden biases in perception and engineering.

concepts.name: Mindfulness
concepts.context: Skills-based approach emphasizing self-awareness and self-regulation; first major wave of Buddhism incorporation in Western organizations with benefits but limited systemic impact.

concepts.name: Compassion
concepts.context: Central to Buddhist practice; increasingly recognized as critical complement to mindfulness in organizational settings and as driver of intelligent perception.

concepts.name: Dukkha
concepts.context: Buddhist concept of suffering or unsatisfactoriness; Bill's experience of his father's death became catalyst for deeper exploration and transformation.

concepts.name: Self-Awareness
concepts.context: Key skill developed through mindfulness training; foundational capacity to understand one's own internal experience and limitations.

concepts.name: Self-Regulation
concepts.context: Capacity to manage one's responses and emotions; core outcome of mindfulness-based interventions in organizations.

concepts.name: Neuroplasticity
concepts.context: Understanding that brain structure and function can be changed through experience and practice; foundational concept enabling Bill's healing journey.

concepts.name: Neo-Buddhism
concepts.context: Adapted form of Buddhism emphasizing neuroscience and psychology; despite limitations, described as utterly healing and transformative for Bill Duane.

concepts.name: Care
concepts.context: Driver of intelligence in the Stress-Care Loop framework; proposed as scale-free concept operating from cellular to super-organizational levels.

concepts.name: Intelligence
concepts.context: Proposed to be driven by care and compassion; contrasted with narrow technical intelligence that misses important causal factors like love and trust.

concepts.name: Blind Spot
concepts.context: Limitation of extrapolatory, reductionist science and engineering; also refers to inner blind spots regarding compassion that manifest in tool-building.

concepts.name: Wholesomeness
concepts.context: Goal of integrating Buddhist wisdom with modern challenges; requires looking beyond narrow domains to broader systemic implications.

concepts.name: Well-Being
concepts.context: Program focus addressing employee mental health, meaning, and purpose; Bill Duane transitioned from engineering executive role to lead this work.

concepts.name: Stress
concepts.context: Initial condition in the Stress-Care Loop; recognition of stress or dukkha can motivate movement toward care and intelligent perception.

concepts.name: Me versus We
concepts.context: Shift in perspective from individual self-interest to collective interdependence; key to accessing problem spaces and solutions unavailable from individual perspective.

concepts.name: Diseases of Despair
concepts.context: Rising phenomenon of mental health crises and substance abuse; indicator of societal disconnection from meaning and purpose.

concepts.name: Epistemic Vulnerability
concepts.context: Susceptibility to misinformation and manipulation; child epistemic vulnerability rate showing lowest levels despite other social challenges.

concepts.name: Attention and Intention Economies
concepts.context: Systems designed to capture and monetize human attention; proposed source of pollution affecting youth spiritual and mental health.

concepts.name: Power
concepts.context: Structural force in society; disruption from AI reaching middle-class professions; correlation between economic activity and life satisfaction.

concepts.name: Large Language Models
concepts.context: AI systems skilled at perspective-taking and narrative generation; demonstrates capability to expand viewpoint beyond individual interest.

concepts.name: Problem Space
concepts.context: Domain of challenges to be solved; organizations with expanded perception and care have greater ability to traverse complex problem spaces.

concepts.name: Interdependence
concepts.context: Fundamental Buddhist principle that all phenomena arise in relation; Bill argues love is the only rational move in realms of true interdependence.

concepts.name: Perception and Cognition
concepts.context: Methods of understanding and knowing; need to develop new approaches to perceive and cognize factors that are important but difficult to measure.

frameworks.name: Search Inside Yourself
frameworks.creator: Bill Duane and Google
frameworks.context: Program bridging ancient wisdom and cutting-edge technology to foster well-being and ethical AI; first major wave of mindfulness in corporate settings.

frameworks.name: Stress-Care Loop
frameworks.creator: Thomas Doctor
frameworks.context: Framework proposing that care is a driver of intelligence; stress/dukkha triggers care, leading to intelligent, grief perception; intended as scale-free model applicable across levels.

frameworks.name: Ajahn Chah Forest Lineage
frameworks.creator: Ajahn Chah
frameworks.context: Buddhist monastic tradition and training lineage; Bill Duane completed five years of teacher training in this tradition.

frameworks.name: Human-AI Hybrid Systems of Care
frameworks.creator: Bill Duane and Olaf Witkowski
frameworks.context: Experimental approach combining human and artificial intelligence with care as central driver; under development at Google X.

institutions.name: Google
institutions.context: Major tech company where Bill Duane worked on search infrastructure, Gmail, and well-being initiatives; launched Search Inside Yourself program.

institutions.name: Amazon
institutions.context: Tech company where Bill Duane worked on machine learning and related initiatives.

institutions.name: Stanford
institutions.context: Institution where Bill Duane teaches innovation and AI.

institutions.name: White House
institutions.context: Location of workshops on machine learning that Bill Duane participated in.

institutions.name: Center For The Study Of Apparent Selves
institutions.context: Organization founded by Thomas Doctor, Olaf Witkowski, and Lisa Solomon; their work redirected Bill Duane's career trajectory.

institutions.name: Center For Compassionate Complexity
institutions.context: Newly launched initiative by Bill Duane and Olaf Witkowski to explore problem spaces at intersection of compassion and complexity.

institutions.name: Google X
institutions.context: Experimental division of Google (Skunk Works); hired Bill Duane and Olaf Witkowski to research and implement Human-AI hybrid systems of care.

institutions.name: Edelman Foundation
institutions.context: Organization that conducted research on trust in government across 28 countries over 20 years showing declining credibility.

questions.question: How can organizations develop perception and cognition of factors that are important but difficult to measure, such as love, trust, meaning, and purpose?
questions.context: Central challenge for implementing care-driven systems in organizations; current engineering approaches optimize for measurable metrics while ignoring critical but unmeasurable factors.

questions.question: Can care and compassion genuinely be operationalized as drivers of intelligence in AI systems and organizations?
questions.context: Bill Duane and collaborators are testing this hypothesis through Human-AI hybrid systems research at Google X.

questions.question: How can we shift from individual self-interest to collective interdependence at organizational and societal scales?
questions.context: Fundamental transformation needed for organizations to address systemic problems; Bill Duane argues this shift makes previously inaccessible solutions available.

questions.question: What are the long-term systemic impacts of mindfulness and well-being programs in corporate settings?
questions.context: First wave of Buddhist-inspired corporate programs showed individual benefits but failed to shift entire systems toward better outcomes as intended.

questions.question: Is AI sentience relevant to how we should build and interact with AI systems?
questions.context: Bill Duane argues the question of AI sentience is less important than our relationship to AI; if we interact with it as sentient, that relationship itself becomes powerful.

questions.question: How can we address the blind spots in both reductionist engineering and human perception that prevent organizations from building ethically sound tools?
questions.context: Bill identifies alignment between external blind spots of reductionist science and internal blind spots regarding compassion and care as major barrier to ethical AI.

questions.question: Can organizations maintain ethical integrity while developing powerful AI tools without enforcing explicit normative or ethical frameworks?
questions.context: Current corporate approach leaves ethics 'fuzzy' to avoid religious impositions, but this creates space for systems to operate without explicit moral guidance.

questions.question: What is the relationship between addressing individual well-being and solving systemic societal problems?
questions.context: Bill Duane's own healing journey and current work suggest individual transformation may be necessary but not sufficient for systemic change.
